titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Church of the Redeemer (New Haven, Conn.) Records
Church of the Redeemer (New Haven, Conn.) Records
titlestmt.author: Compiled by Calvert D. Morgan, Jr.; Martha Lund Smalley

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Monday March 25, 2019 at 22:29

did.unittitle: Church of the Redeemer (New Haven, Conn.) Records
did.abstract: Extensive reports, minutes, publications, photographs, scrapbooks, etc. document the history of The Church of the Redeemer, United Church of Christ (New Haven, Conn).

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Church of the Redeemer (New Haven, Conn.)

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Chapel Street Congregational Church (New Haven, Conn.)

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: Historical statement by Elliott Barske, Church Historian

In 1838 the City of New Haven celebrated its bicentennial year and the fourth Congregational Church in the area came into being when on November 4th the Chapel Street Congregational Church was organized and declared a Church of Christ with 61 members. This congregation was eventually to become the Church of the Redeemer.

Two hundred years before in 1638, the New Haven Colony was settled under the leadership of Reverend John Davenport and Theophilus Eaton who established the First Church, now Center Church on the Green. Gradually over the early years schisms arose and the period of The Great Awakening and the teachings of Jonathan Edwards led to the formation of dissenting groups such as the White Haven Church and the Fair Haven Society. These two groups merged in 1796 to form North Church on the Green, the Second Church of New Haven, now known as United Church.

The Third Congregational Church was formed in 1826 under the leadership of Dr. Nathaniel W. Taylor, a Professor of Theology in Yale College and a former pastor of Center Church. The founding members of the Third included 19 from Center Church and 10 from United Church. This congregation was disrupted after a new pastor, Dr. E. L. Cleaveland, who was installed in 1833, would not accept the "new theology" of Nathaniel Taylor. Many members of Third stood by Dr. Taylor and under his spiritual guidance organized and founded the Chapel Street Congregational Church. At the organization meeting Timothy Dwight, Jr., son of the President of Yale, acted as Chairman and became very active in the government of the new church.

During the over 170 years of our history, there have been 17 Pastors of whom the longest serving were Reverend John E. Todd 1869-1890 and Reverend Watson L. Phillips 1890-1915. Both were serving during the two major relocations of the church. Todd was present when our Second House of Worship at Orange and Wall Streets was dedicated on May 25, 1871 and the name changed to the Church of the Redeemer. Phillips was involved in the move to Cold Spring Street and Whitney Ave where the Parish House was dedicated on October 10, 1920. After 30 years of planning and fund raising the present Main Sanctuary was completed and dedicated on May 20, 1951 during the pastorate of the Reverend Robert E. Luccock.

MINISTRIES PAST TO PRESENT Rev. John O. Colton 1839-1840 Rev. Joseph P. Thompson 1840-1845 Rev. Leverett Griggs 1845-1847 Rev. William T. Eustis 1848-1869 Rev. John E. Todd 1869-1890 Rev. Watson L. Phillips 1890-1915 Rev. Roy M. Houghton 1917-1931 Rev. R. Hawley Fitch 1932-1935 Rev. Phillip G. Scott 1936-1949 Rev. Robert E. Luccock 1950-1962 Rev. Charles L. Ives 1962-1964 Rev. C. Arthur Bradley 1964-1981 Rev. Dr. Thomas Burgett-Leutner 1981-1994 Rev. Olivia Robinson 1994-1996 (interim) Rev. Lillian F. Daniel 1996-2004 Rev. Dr. Duncan Newcomer 2004-2006 (interim) Rev. Dr. Rochelle A. Stackhouse 2006-2017.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of the Church of the Redeemer, transferred from New Haven Museum, 2017

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The original finding aid for the collection, compiled by Calvert D. Morgan, Jr. provides the following description of the collection: The papers of the Church of the Redeemer arrived at the New Haven Colony Historical Society in fairly haphazard arrangement, having been stored, some for over a century, in boxes, bags, and even an old leather suitcase. Though a few had suffered minor water damage, and others needed cleaning, for the most part the papers had been well preserved; the vast majority were transferred directly into folders. The order into which the collection has been arranged reflects the historical organization of the church, and the fourteen individual series into which the papers have been divided serve as a guide to the church's operations as well as to the papers themselves. The most important body of information, the papers on the history of the church, are at the head of the collection, and the arrangement descends from there.

A few matters warrant special attention, either because of their exceptional nature or because they might not be immediately apparent to the researcher. First, it bears mention that in the 1930s, the Church of the Redeemer gave an important part of their papers to the Connecticut State Library; these were photostatically copied, and the bound copies returned to the church. Those volumes occupy the first two boxes of the collection. The papers in Series 2, Annual Reports to the Church 1843-1978, fall naturally into two halves. Before the year 1937, the reports were submitted individually, and remained scattered throughout the church files; but beginning in 1937, the reports were compiled into a booklet of Annual Reports. In most cases, we have two copies of this booklet; in many, one copy was the Pastor's personal copy, with his marginal notes and emendations.

The collection of Church Calendars, by far the largest single body of papers in the collection, presents a similar situation; along with the primary set of calendars covering 1893-1976, a separate set of calendars for the years 1939-1962 was kept by the church organist, and his notes make this set an important adjunct to the larger collection. The same procedure was followed for the set of Church Directories in Series 6; directories with emendations were kept along with clean copies wherever possible.

Finally, the body of papers which comprises Series 13 of the collection, and which I have called the Mimeographed Materials Scrapbooks Collection, merits a word of explanation. This part of the collection represents the effort of the Church Secretary to keep a record of everything which was mimeographed for church purposes between the years of 1929 and 1957. Though this is an impractical research tool, it is nevertheless an important and discrete part of the collection, and an invaluable resource for the study of those years. Furthermore, although many of the items in this series duplicate other items in the collection, much of the information is unique to this part of the collection; for instance, Series 13 stands as the sole detailed account of the doings of the church Forum for students during the 1940s and 1950s.

It is important to note that information within the records of the Church of the Redeemer, because of the record-keeping conventions of the Church, can occasionally be found in a number of places; probably the most important example of this difficulty is in the matter of such information as birth, baptism,marriage, and death records. By the logic of the collection, such information would naturally fall into the category of membership records, and thus should be found in the papers of Series 6. Yet because the church rarely kept separate records of such statistics, in most cases it would be more efficient to consult the records of the Advisory Board of the Church, or, in earlier cases, the records of the Church Clerk or the Standing committee. Similar situations may occur as well in the pursuit of other information; the researcher is encouraged to follow as many avenues as become necessary in order to get the most out of the collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in 14 series:
Series 1: The History of the Chapel Street Congregational Church and the Church of the Redeemer
Series 2: Annual Reports to the Church
Series 3: Records of Administrative and Governing Bodies of the Church
Series 4: Financial Records of the Church
Series 8: Records of the Buildings of the Church
Series 9: Records of the Committees of the Church
Series 10: Records of the Organizations of the Church
Series 11: Records of the Pastors and Associate Pastors of the Church

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Church of the Redeemer (New Haven, Conn.) Records (RG 266), Special Collections, Yale Divinity School Library.

Records of the Pastors and Associate Pastors of the Church
Papers of John Owen Colton (1810-1840), Pastor of the Chapel Street Congregational Church (1839-1840)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Salary receipts, receipt of the service of the hearse at Colton's funeral, April 23, 1840; receipt of Colton's rent payment (by his estate), May 1840; receipt for mahogany coffin and shroud; receipt for "begging grace" at Colton's funeral; typescript copy of obituary from Chapel Street record, 1840; 2 photos of Colton's monument in Grove Street Cemetery

did.unittitle: Papers of Joseph P. Thompson (b. 1819), Pastor of Chapel Street Congregational Church (1840-1845)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 3 salary receipts; :"Habitual Thankfulness. A Discourse delivered in the Chapel Street Congregational Church, New Haven, November 19, 1840"; "A Plea for Religious Newspapers. A Sermon preached to his own people on the Lord's Day, December 29th, 1844, by a Connecticut Pastor"; "Lewdness and Murder [cover page reads "Licentiousness and Murder]: A Discourse suggested by the Late Murder [in New Haven]; delivered in the Chapel Street Congregational Church, on evening, March 9th, 1845; and repeated in the Center Churches of New Haven and Hartford. [1845]"; In Memoriam: Rev. Joseph P. Thompson, D. D., by Rev. John E. Todd, Pastor of the Church of the Redeemer

did.unittitle: Papers of Joseph P. Thompson after his departure from the Chapel Street Congregational Church

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Vice Progressive: A Sermon to Young Men; Preached in the Broadway Tabernacle, August 2nd, 1846"; Certificate of Marriage signed by Thompson, Oct 1850; "The Tabernacle: A Spirit and a Building; An Historical Sermon by Rev. Allan Knight Chalmers, D. D., May 12, 1935," with discussion of Rev. Thompson's ministry at the Tabernacle

did.unittitle: Papers of Leverett Griggs, Pastor of the Chapel Street Congregational Church (1845-1847)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Including undated photo of Griggs; Sermon by Rev. Joel Hawes, D. D., found wih Griggs's papers; 2 money-orders signed by Griggs, both 1847

did.unittitle: Papers of William T. Eustis, Pastor of the Chapel Street Congregational Church (1848-1869)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter from Eustis resigning pastorate, 1857; vote of Church to reject resignation; to the Church to reconsider from Eustis; letter from Eustis re-accepting pastorate; Discourse delivered on the Twentieth Anniversary of the Origin of the Chapel Street Church and Ecclesiastical Society", 1858 by Eustis

did.unittitle: Papers of John E. Todd (1833-1917), Pastor of the Chapel Street Congregational Church and of the Church of the Redeemer (1869-1890)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two photos of Todd, one dated 1889; letter of acceptance, 1869; Order of Exercises for the Installation of John E. Todd, 1869; letter from Todd to Church re moving Church location, 1870; "Topics", announcement of "Bible Reading" discussion by Todd, 1882; Program of Dedication of the New Edifice of the Chapel Street Church and Society (Church of the Redeemer), 1871; typescript of passage of Atwater's History of New Haven re the Church of the Redeemer; Todd's letter of resignation, 1890; papers on resignation of Todd; clippings on Todd's sermons and death; reprint of first New Haven District Telephone Co. Directory, listing Todd as first client

did.unittitle: Writings of John E. Todd

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "The Sabbath Made for Man: A Sermon Preached in the Chapel Street Church, New Haven, Conn., January 23, 1871" ; "A Memento of Communion Sabbath", July 7, 1878 ; "Drunkenness a Curse, not a Blessing:; A review of a paper by Rev. John E. Todd on Drunkenness a Vice, not a Disease 1883; Reprint of article: "New Theology", from the Bibliotecha Sacra, 1886; "Serious Talk with Mr. Patrick", 1885; "A Plain, Old-Fashioned Woman's Complaint", 1888

did.unittitle: Papers of Watson Lyman Phillips: (1850-1944), Pastor of the Church: of the Redeemer (1890-1915)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two small photos; photo oi four pastors: Phillips, Houghton, Fitch, Scott, taken 1938; call to council for Phillips's Installation 1890; Minutes of Council; Order of Exercises of Phillips's Installation, 1890; Conn. Bible Society Reports, 1899, with article by Phillips; "The Palms of Elim", sermon preached 1897; "Criticism and Constancy", sermon preached 1897; letter from Phillips to Society's Committee, 1909; clippings on Phillips; resolution on Phillips on his resignation, 1915; letter from Phillips to Roy M. Houghton, 1923; Wedding Service performed by Phillips, 1924; invitation to testimonial dinner for Phillips's 80th birthday, 1930; program of dinner; clippings on Phillips's birthdays, wedding anniversaries, etc., death

did.unittitle: Pastor Phillips' summary of his years with the church 1890-1915
Papers of Associate Ministers of Church: Harry E. Peabody, 1896-1900; Jay T. Stocking (1870-1936), 1901-1903; John Deyo, 1904-1905.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photo of Peabody; program of lnstallation of Peabody; minutes of Ecclesiastical Council on Stocking, 1901; "Immortality", memorial booklet on Stocking, 1936; Resignation of Stocking, 1903; Farewell poem to Stocking; minutes of Ecclesiastical Council on Deyo, 1910; Resolution on resignation of Deyo, 1911

did.unittitle: Papers of Roy M. Houghton (1876-1958), Pastor of the Church of the Redeemer (1916-1931)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photo of Houghton; photo of four pastors: Phillips, Houghton, Fitch, Scott, taken 1938; Program of Installation of Houghton, 1917; Program of Radio Lectures given by Houghton; "With the Yankee Division in France", c. 1919; letter of resignation, 1931; letter re resignation, 1931; call for special Church meeting on resignaton, 1931; resolutions on Houghton; correspondence re Houghton's resignation; Funeral service performed by Houghton, 1951; clippings on Houghton's resignation and death

did.unittitle: Papers of R. Hawley Fitch, Pastor of the Church of the Redeemer (1931-1935)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photo of Fitch; photo of four pastors: Phillips, Houghton, Fitch, Scott, taken 1938; Report of the Pastoral Committee on Fitch, 1931; Call to Installation of Fitch, 1932; Service of Installation of Fitch, 1932; Clippings on Fitch's arrival and departure from the Church

did.unittitle: Papers on the Resignation of R. Hawley Fitch

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter of Resignation; call for special meeting of Church to consider resignation, 1935; minutes of special meeting; motion of meeting to request that Fitch reconsider; Fitch's reaffirmation of position; minutes of special church meeting accepting resignation with regret; Letter to Fitch on success of his pastorate; Correspondence re resignation and transfer, 1935

did.unittitle: Papers of Philip Gordon Scott; ( b. 1904), Pastor of the Church of the Redeemer (1936-1949)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photo of four pastors: Phillips, Houghton, Fitch, Scott, taken 1938; clippings re Scott's arrival and installation, 1936; minutes of special meeting of church re Scott's installation, 1936; special meeting of New Haven West Assoc. re installation; Service of Installation ; first pastoral letter, 1936; Wedding Service written by· Scott, 1948; Article by Scott: "What do Congregationalists Believe?", 1938; pages 3 and 4 of a 4-page sermon by Scott, 1938; "The Passing of the Saint": sermon by Scott, 1941; letter to Church re Scott, 1938; letter to Scott, 1937; clippings on Scott's reception at departure, and on his role as departing Chairman of the General Council of Congregational Christian Churches; program of rededication of Westmoreland Congregational Church, of which Scott became pastor, 1950

did.unittitle: Papers of Robert E. Luccock (b .1915), Pastor of the Church of the Redeemer (1949-1962)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence of Pastoral Committee re Luccock, 1949; clippings on Luccock's arrival; invitation to reception for Luccocks, 1949; Installation program, 1950; pamphlet on Luccock and family; Sermons: "Life, Liberty and the Pursuit of Holiness" ( 1951); "On Account of God" (1951); "This is the Only Victory--Our Faith" (1951); "When Pain Brings God to Our Side" (1952);"Making the Best of our Second Best" (1952); "America's Greatest Peril: Our Worship of Half-Gods" (1952); "If God is Good, Why Does He Permit Evil?" (1960); "Is There Life After Death?" (1960); Letter of resignation, 1962; clippings on departure

did.unittitle: Papers of Thomas G. Campbell (b. 1933), Minister of Education and Parish, Church of the Redeemer (1958-1961)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Call to Campbell, 1958; pamphlet on Campbell; Report of the Minister of Education and Parish Life, 1960; outline and report of Kathy and Tom Campbell, 1960

did.unittitle: Papers of Charles L. Ives (b. 1914), Pastor of the Church of the Redeemer (1962-1964)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Call to Ecclesiastical Council for Installation, 1962; Installation Service, 1962; Pamphlet on Ives and family; clipping on death of Mrs. Ives, 1963; sermon by Ives "Satan and Christ", 1964

did.unittitle: Papers of Charles G. Christianson, Associate Minister of the Church of the Redeemer (1961-1963)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Terms of the Call by the Church of the Redeemer to the Rev. Charles G. Christianson, 1961; Ministerial Record of Christianson; pamphlet on Christianson (2c); sermon: "And Now that the Inheritance is Ours", 1963; clipping on Christianson's departure

did.unittitle: Papers of C. Arthur Bradley (b. 1927), Pastor of the Church of the Redeemer (1964-1980)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photo of Bradley; letter extending call to Bradley, 1964; Press release re call to Bradley, 1964; invitation to reception for Bradley, 1964; Installation Service Program for Bradley, 1964; copy of letter of resignation from church newsletter, 1980; sermons and prayers

did.unittitle: Writings of C. Arthur Bradley

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Towards a Christian Ethic for Today": Installation Paper, 1964; Untitled sermon , 1965 ; "Dead to Sin and Alive to God" , 1965 ; "He Who Loves Is Born of God", 1965; Untitled sermon, 1965; "A World Come of Age", 1967; "Black Power and White Fear"' 1967; "You Weary God!" 1967; "Dealing With the Death Wish", 1967; "God Was in Christ", 1967; "The Church of the Future, II", 1968

did.unittitle: Papers of Frederick W. Lyon, Associate Minister of the Church of the Redeemer (1965-1967)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Clipping re Lyon's appointment; Installation Service Program, 1965; Installation paper: "Church Stewardship as Man's Prime Response to God", 1965

did.unittitle: Papers of Thomas Burgett Leutner, Franklin Bower, Lillian Daniel
Photographs and Books

Photographs of the Chapel Street Congregational Church building, corner of Chapel and Union Streets: 1 stereoscopic view of interior; interior photo; photo of interior, copy from microfilmed scrapbook in collection

Photographs of the Church of the Redeemer building, corner of Orange and Wall Streets: large interior photo presented to Church by Henry M. Osborn, 1938, with accompanying caption; small square exterior photo; 2 larger exterior photos; 1 exterior photo on card, with caption "Compliments of the Adult Class"
Photographs of the temporary Church Home, Whitney Ave. and Cold Spring Street: 1 large exterior photo of groundbreaking ceremonies for new Parish House, with temporary Church Home in background

Photographs of the Church Parish House, Whitney Ave. and Cold Spring Street: postcard of artist's rendering; 1 photo of interior decorated for Christmas; 1 large early interior photo, 1920; photo of cornerstone-laying exercises, 1914

Photographs of New Sanctuary, Whitney Avenue and Cold Spring Street: color slides of communion elements; 5 photos of different parts of interior of church; 2 photos, 1 larger print of interior of church; mounted prints of slides of communion elements, interior of church; exterior photo
Photo prints and uncut sheet of proofs of photos of Vacation School 1957 and Church School 1958

Photographs of the Sunday School: group photo 1900; Maude Stone's class 1905; photo of Sunday School meeting in Corner House Kitchen; large print and cropped print of Sunday School classes and officers 1912; photo of Luther Shao's class, 1932-1933
